annotation.TEXT: Fuma can be freely controlled in any direction, much like Indonesian Artifact's version of this weapon. Similar to that version, this one is also terrible for exactly the same reason: You can't control your own movements while aiming this thing around. It would be one thing if it had ungodly damage output, huge range, and high speed (e.g., Phantom Fuse) - but it's pretty average in all of those aspects.

Napalm Man's stage is home to my personal favorite track in the game. I still have no idea what the source behind it is (along with several other tracks in this game), but I'll probably try to compile a list for reference as they're pointed out and hopefully uploaded to YouTube later on.

Rush Jet basically goes very fast and eats up ammo like nobody's business. Even though it seemingly gives Rush some cool shades in the process (or at least, it looks like it at first), there's only one instance in this game where you need to use it. Beyond that, Super Arrow is generally a better option.

Crystal Man's stage is probably my favorite level in this hack. Admittedly, this is partly due to the music choice and subtle reference that goes with it. I may not have gotten the Phoenix Wright reference with Gravity Man at first, but this one I did manage to catch onto.

Crystal Man lost his 4-way spread attack in this game, but in exchange, his standard projectiles have picked up the mechanic of bouncing off surfaces. He also seems to be capable of jumping multiple times in mid-air for some reason (whether or not this is a glitch or intentional, I can't say).

Front Blast is somewhat reminicent of the Trinitro Blast from Unlimited, except this weapon creates a single explosion a set distance away from Mega Man's current position. Although it's rather powerful to the point of potentially one-shoting most enemies, the hit-box on this thing feels a bit off (it doesn't seem to work well unless you catch something in the direct center of the explosion).

I'm honestly not sure how this is even possible, but the Power Stone in this game is even worse than the original one. Square Orbit fires out a single, slow moving rock that travels in a diamond-shaped pattern, which stops briefly at set points to change its trajectory. The rock itself spreads out its range the further it travels, but this aspect is practically never useful on account of how slow it is. The rock also despawns if it happens to go off-screen at any point.

The standard Metools in this hack are actually kind of tough. Their typical 3-way spread shot has been changed to a large, singular projectile. The tiny mets they produce after being killed are also much faster and more annoying to deal with than usual. Front Blast works well at taking them all out in one shot, provided you get them in the center of the explosion.

Contrary to most of the other bosses, Gyro Man is actually a bit slower this time around. He still throws out projectiles at a decent pace, but he seems to take his time when preparing to lift-off. He also produces a propeller each time he lands, which automatically flies towards you after a few seconds.

Reflect Ball is pretty decent for the most part. Aside from hosting the obvious trait of bouncing off things, it has average damage output and can be fired in 8 directions. While not terribly useful in most cases, it's actually very helpful for one particular fortress boss.

Aside from the terrain in his boss room, Napalm Man hasn't changed a whole lot. Overall, he's a bit faster and tends to jump more often, along with his main projectiles only consisting of Napalm Bombs now.

Stone Man's only major change comes from the weird, but relatively harmless paths his projectiles take. Combined with the new layout of his room and the fact that he jumps around more frequently, he's actually easier to fight than his original version.
